web_research.query: What are winning approaches for text classification with metadata features on Kaggle?
web_research.finding:
Winning Kaggle solutions for text‑classification tasks that also contain structured metadata usually treat the extra fields as a **second modality** and fuse them with the language model rather than ignoring them.  The most effective patterns that have emerged in recent competitions are:

* **Metadata‑driven weak supervision** – The META framework builds a text‑rich graph that links documents with their metadata (author, timestamp, venue, etc.) and extracts “seed motifs” that act as additional weak labels.  By iteratively expanding seed words and motifs, the classifier learns from both text and highly predictive metadata cues, often beating pure‑text baselines on real‑world datasets ([arXiv 2023](https://export.arxiv.org/pdf/2301.01808v1.pdf)).  
* **Multimodal deep networks** – Approaches such as MESSAGENET process each metadata type (categorical, numerical, image, audio) in a dedicated neural block, then jointly train all blocks so that cross‑channel interactions are learned end‑to‑e

web_research.query: How do Kaggle winners handle moderate class imbalance in text classification competitions?
web_research.finding:
Based on insights from Kaggle winners and the practical techniques shared in competition write‑ups, moderate class imbalance in text‑classification contests is usually tackled with a short, repeatable workflow ([Neptune blog](https://neptune.ai/blog/text-classification-tips-and-tricks-kaggle-competitions); [AIcrowd notebook](https://www.aicrowd.com/showcase/dealing-with-class-imbalance)):

1. **Quantify the imbalance** – compute the label frequencies on the training set and on the validation split; if any class represents < 20 % of the data, treat it as “moderately imbalanced.” ([AIcrowd](https://www.aicrowd.com/showcase/dealing-with-class-imbalance))

2. **Apply class‑aware sample weighting** – pass a weight vector to the loss function (e.g., `torch.nn.BCEWithLogitsLoss(pos_weight=…)` or `sklearn`’s `class_weight='balanced'`). This forces the optimizer to penalize mistakes on minority classes more heavily. ([AIcrowd](https://www.aicrowd.com/showcase/dealing-with-class-imbalance))
